title: Meridian gym teacher was under investigation by Midland County Sheriff
body_text:
Meridian Public Schools physical education teacher Joshua Long was under investigation by the Midland County Sheriff’s Department after a report that he initiated a wrestling match with an 8-year-old female student.
Midland County Sheriff Myron Greene said Thursday the investigation was complete and the report was sent to the Midland County Prosecutor's Office.

"There was no criminal intent by the teacher, and I believe that is the way the prosecutor will view it as well," Greene said.
Heather Parker, the girl's mother, said Long initiated a "wrestling match" on March 4 on the football field with her daughter, though she was running track. Her daughter is part of the Meridian Youth Wrestling Team. Parker said Long grabbed her shoulders and pulled the girl to the ground. Her daughter told her that after she rolled onto her belly, Long rolled her onto her back, lay on her and pinned her.
In a social media post, Parker said her daughter yelled, "'Get off me, old man.' (She said) she was so uncomfortable. She proceeded to run away."

"I am an advocate for women’s wrestling!" Parker said in the social media post. "I have spent so much time learning from some amazing coaches. And spent so much time on the mat. I will be the first one to jump and help if needed. But I believe strongly (there is an) appropriate time and place for things."
Parker said she discussed the incident with Meridian Public Schools Superintendent Sarah Glann.
Glann told her that Long would receive a two-week suspension for his behavior and the superintendent apologized for the incident, Parker said.

"I can't imagine what this man was even thinking," Parker told the Daily News.
The Daily News contacted Glann for comment on March 15. On March 21, Glann declined to confirm for the Daily News that Long was suspended by the school district. She did say, “We take the safety of our students as the highest priority always from me and for the district.”
“I’m not going to comment on specific employee issues,” Glann said.
Glann did not know whether there was a wrestling unit in the school’s curriculum.

"I can't confirm nor deny that they do," Glann said.
Greene said the teacher admitted to grappling with the 8-year-old girl, who was not injured.
"I would say it may have not been appropriate for that time and place, but it wasn't criminal," Greene said.

Long was hired by the district in September 2015.
